title: AB 451
content: The people of California enact the following. Section 21107.8 of the Vehicle Code allows cities or counties to declare privately owned offstreet parking facilities open for public use, with regulations on unauthorized parking. If a city or county enacts an ordinance allowing privately owned offstreet parking facilities to regulate unauthorized parking, the owner must include contest instructions in parking fee invoices. If a city or county authorizes privately owned offstreet parking facilities to regulate unauthorized parking, the owner must include contest instructions in parking fee invoices and cannot use the Department of Motor Vehicles to collect unpaid fees. An ordinance or resolution enacted for offstreet parking facilities must have a notice posted at each entrance warning of public moving vehicle laws and potential parking invoice fees. A parking receipt must also warn drivers of possible fees. Additionally, no ordinance can be enacted without a public hearing and prior notice to the facility owner and operator. The enforcement of parking regulations at privately owned offstreet parking facilities requires a parking receipt to warn of potential fees. An ordinance must undergo a public hearing and provide notice to the facility owner and operator. Section 22507.8 can be enforced without the need for an ordinance or notice at each entrance. The department is not obligated to patrol or enforce code provisions at these facilities, except for those related to private property. The department is not required to patrol or enforce code provisions at privately owned offstreet parking facilities, except for those related to private property. Cities or counties authorizing private parking regulation must include dispute resolution procedures in their ordinance, including a written policy with specified time periods and an administrative hearing process. The dispute resolution policy for private parking regulation must include specified time periods and an administrative hearing process with options for in-person or mail hearings, administrative review, and a hearing by a trained third-party examiner. The examiner's decision must be delivered personally or by mail, with the option for payment in installments for those unable to pay in full. Incentives based on the number of invoices or disputed charges are prohibited, and there is a cap on parking invoice fees. The private parking regulation includes a prohibition on incentives based on the number of invoices or disputed charges, a cap on parking invoice fees, and measures to prevent the regulator from posing as a government agency.
